title: Democrat Robert Martwick Sworn in as State Senator; GOP Taps Rosemont Mayor Brad Stephens for House Seat

annotations.text: "We will do whatever it takes to win," Stephens said.
annotations.openFeedback: This is a short, punchy, motivational phrase focused on victory rather than policy substance. It functions as a campaign-style slogan aimed at rallying support and determination, fitting the 'slogans' subcategory of persuasive propaganda.

title: Frozen Sperm Bank Could Be Set up in Space, Study Suggests

annotations.text: Sperm banks could one day be set up in space, scientists have predicted.
annotations.openFeedback: Neutral, descriptive scientific statement without emotional, divisive, or persuasive language; it simply reports a prediction based on research.

title: Phoenix Chief Says Police Response to Incident with 4-year-old Is 'unacceptable'

annotations.text: this is one of the most insane attacks on a black family, or any family, that I've ever seen law enforcement engage in
annotations.openFeedback: This statement characterizes the incident as among the "most insane attacks" the speaker has ever seen, using extreme, superlative language that amplifies the severity of the event beyond a neutral or measured description.

annotations.text: I, like many others, am sick over what I have seen in the video
annotations.openFeedback: The phrase appeals to a sense of shared outrage ("like many others"), implying that a broad group feels this way and encouraging the audience to align with that majority emotional reaction.

title: Four Top Residencies Now Offered to Local Artists, Thanks to Oolite

annotations.text: a new opportunity to superpower their careers
annotations.openFeedback: This phrase uses promotional, amplified language that overstates the impact of the residencies on artistsâ€™ careers, going beyond a neutral or factual description and fitting the definition of exaggeration.

title: Port of L.a. Sued After Canceling Agreement for a Shipping Container Facility

annotations.text: a green, job-creating project is stymied by a single entity for their own narrow reasons
annotations.openFeedback: This quote disparages the union as a self-interested obstructionist "single entity" acting for "narrow reasons," using negatively loaded language to characterize them rather than focusing on specific actions or evidence.

title: Get These Trending Washington Restaurants on Your Radar Today

annotations.text: Washington's buzziest local spots
annotations.openFeedback: The phrase uses an informal superlative ("buzziest") to hype the restaurants as especially exciting or popular, going beyond a neutral description of their review data.

annotations.text: which spots are riding a trend, right now
annotations.openFeedback: This dramatizes normal changes in popularity as if they are part of a notable, urgent trend, adding promotional excitement rather than neutrally reporting review increases.

annotations.text: bagged a staggering 141.7% increase in new reviews
annotations.openFeedback: The adjective "staggering" amplifies the numerical increase to sound unusually dramatic and impressive, functioning as hype rather than neutral description.

annotations.text: Columbia Heights' Rooster & Owl is also making waves
annotations.openFeedback: The figurative phrase "making waves" inflates the perceived impact and prominence of the restaurant beyond what the review statistics alone establish.

annotations.text: CIRCA at Navy Yard is the city's buzziest traditional American spot
annotations.openFeedback: Calling it the "buzziest" traditional American spot overstates its status and popularity in a promotional way, rather than neutrally conveying its review growth.

title: South African Woman Reunited with Son Six Years After He Disappeared and Was Tracked Down 1,000 Miles Away

annotations.text: The pictures and footage only scratch the surface of the tale: wide smiles, and the tears of joy of a mother and her son, reunited after six years.
annotations.openFeedback: This article is a human-interest story. While it uses emotional language to describe the events, it does so in a way that is appropriate for the narrative and does not employ any of the defined inflammatory or propagandistic techniques.

title: Ex-Posen Mayor Pleads Guilty to Embezzling Village Funds

annotations.text: The entire article is a factual report of a legal proceeding.
annotations.openFeedback: All three annotators identify the language as neutral and factual. The article describes legal actions, allegations, and context without exaggeration, demonization, or other polarizing techniques, so it is best captured with a single overarching 'No Polarizing language' annotation.

title: Rosemount Recreation Center Plan Gets Positive Response so Far

annotations.text: While a study on whether to proceed with a new recreation center in Rosemount continues, early results are mostly positive.
annotations.openFeedback: The article is a straightforward local news report on a city project. It uses neutral language, quotes officials, and presents factual information without any inflammatory or persuasive propaganda techniques.

title: Ridgecrest Earthquakes Caused Damage to the Earth's Crust Seen from Satellite

annotations.text: Damage to the earth's crust from the 6.4 and 7.1 magnitude earthquakes that struck Southern California last week is visible in a kaleidoscopic satellite image released by NASA.
annotations.openFeedback: The article is a neutral, factual report about earthquakes and satellite imagery. It does not use emotional, inflammatory, or persuasive language, nor does it target or blame any group.

title: Protest in Madrid as Conservatives Suspend Ban on Most Polluting Cars

annotations.text: Thousands protested in Madrid on Saturday against the suspension of curbs on polluting cars by the new conservative city hall
annotations.openFeedback: The reference to "Thousands" protesting highlights the size of the crowd to imply broad public opposition and create social pressure, fitting the bandwagon technique where popularity is used as a persuasive cue.

annotations.text: "Yes we can, I do want Madrid central," chanted the protesters.
annotations.openFeedback: This chant is a short, memorable phrase used collectively by protesters to rally support and express a clear political demand, which aligns with the definition of a slogan.

annotations.text: Some were holding banners that read "I want to breathe free"
annotations.openFeedback: This phrase is concise and emotionally charged, simplifying complex environmental and regulatory issues into a memorable demand, which is characteristic of slogan use in persuasion.

annotations.text: "We aspire to have a Madrid without smoke"
annotations.openFeedback: This aspirational, easily repeatable phrase on banners promotes a clear pro-environment stance and functions as a slogan to mobilize support.

annotations.text: raising fears that environmental rollbacks seen in the United States may be spreading to Europe
annotations.openFeedback: The wording amplifies a local policy change into a broader, cross-continental threat by suggesting a spread of U.S.-style rollbacks to Europe, which may overstate the evidence and thus fits exaggeration.

annotations.text: Madrid's then far-left government banned most petrol and diesel cars from its center
annotations.openFeedback: The term "far-left" is a loaded ideological label that can evoke strong reactions and frame the previous administration in partisan terms rather than neutrally, fitting the name-calling category of inflammatory language.

title: Missouri's Only Abortion Clinic to Remain Open After Judge's Injunction Holds

annotations.text: embattled health center
annotations.openFeedback: The adjective "embattled" is a loaded label that frames the clinic as a sympathetic party under siege, rather than using neutral terminology.

annotations.text: medically unnecessary hoops and regulations
annotations.openFeedback: The phrase characterizes the regulations as entirely unnecessary and merely obstructive, using the metaphor "hoops" to amplify their negative portrayal without engaging with their specific content or possible rationale.

annotations.text: another medically unnecessary requirement that the state was putting on it to whittle down Missouri residents' access to abortion
annotations.openFeedback: This wording presents the requirement as purely unnecessary and part of a deliberate effort to reduce access, simplifying complex regulatory motives into a one-sided, negatively charged narrative.
